text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 6.800.4, Lactation Program.
Changes title from IRS Nursing Mothers Program to Lactation Program.
updates the Program Scope and Objectives subsection as required by IRM
, Internal Management Document System, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process, including adding the program controls subsection. IRM
reorganize and restructure eligibility, enrollment, participation and withdrawing from the program information. IRM
) adds that all employees who identify themselves as having a need to express milk are eligible for the Lactation Program, regardless of tenure. IRM
) adds that employees have the right to participate in the Lactation Program without
IRM 6.800.4.2(1) adds that all employees who identify themselves as having a need to express milk are eligible for the Lactation Program, regardless of tenure.
IRM 6.800.4.2(2) adds that employees have the right to participate in the Lactation Program without fear of retaliation or adverse action.

IRM 6.800.4.3.1(2) and IRM 6.800.4.8(4) clarify the contact for concerns requiring immediate attention that are not resolved within one workday from the Senior Commissioner’s Representative (SCR) Office and the Lactation Program Office (the Human Capital Office (HCO), Office of Human Resources Operations (OHRO), Human Resources Shared Services (HRSS), Work-Life and Leave Sharing Office) to the Lactation Program Office only via an OS GetServices ticket.

IRM 6.800.4.3(3)(d) and 6.800.4.3.1(4) update the supply (hand sanitizer and disinfecting wipes) from submitting a request ticket to Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) to using the employee’s current supply request process.

IRM 6.800.4.4(2)(a) provides participants who do not have access to a computer as part of their job duties, access to a computer to complete the online optional exit questionnaire, instead of a paper copy.

IRM 6.800.4.5(6) adds that within 12 months of the birth of the child, an employee may request to use, if eligible, paid parental leave (PPL) under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) to express milk.
Removes the term “Nursing Mother” and replaces it with the term “Lactation Program participant,” “participant,” and “employee” throughout IRM.

Removes the word “mother” and changes pronouns she, her and herself, to they, their and themselves throughout IRM, to ensure compliance on gender neutrality in accordance with Executive Order 13988, Preventing and Combating Discrimination on the Basis of Gender Identity or Sexual Orientation, dated January 20, 2021.
This IRM supersedes IRM 6.800.4, IRS Nursing Mothers Program dated March 31, 2017.

) Purpose: This IRM provides policy and guidance for the Lactation Program. Read and interpret this policy in accordance with applicable federal laws, gov- ernmentwide regulations, Treasury Human Capital Issuance System Directives and other sources as appropriate. (

) Audience: Unless otherwise indicated, the policies, authorities and instructions in this IRM apply to all business units. Bargaining unit (BU) employees should review negotiated memorandum of understanding (MOU) and agreement sions relating to subjects in this IRM. Should any of these instructions conﬂict with a provision in the MOU or negotiated agreement, the MOU or agreement prevails. (
) Policy Owner: The IRS Human Capital Officer. (
) Program Owner: The Human Capital Office (HCO), Office of Human Resources Operations (OHRO), Human Resources Shared Services (HRSS). (
) Primary Stakeholders : a. HCO, Office of Human Resources Strategy (OHRS), Policy and Audits (P&A) b. Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) (
) Program Goals: This IRM provides Servicewide policy and guidance to all business units to achieve a supportive environment to enable employees to express milk during business hours. (
) This IRM provides policy and guidance on Lactation Program participation, lactation breaks, additional work schedule ﬂexibilities and the designated lactation room and scheduling. (
) Laws: United States Code (USC), at https://www.govinfo.gov/app/collection/ uscode a. Title
(r), Reasonable break time for nursing mothers, at https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/USCODE-
, Preventing and Combating Discrimination on the Basis of Gender Identity or Sexual Orientation, at https://www.whitehouse.gov/ brieﬁng-room/presidential-actions/
) Presidential Delegation of Authority: On December

, President Obama delegated his authority to prescribe regulations for employees in the Executive Branch, to the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to provide appropriate workplace accommodations for Executive Branch civilian employees who need to express milk during working hours, at https:// obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/
Program Owner: The Human Capital Office (HCO), Office of Human Resources Operations (OHRO), Human Resources Shared Services (HRSS).

) Treasury Human Capital Issuance System (HCIS): TN-
, Enhancing Workplace Flexibilities and Work-Life Programs, dated April
) The IRS Human Capital Officer is the executive responsible for this IRM overall Servicewide policy for work-life and wellness programs. (
) The HCO, OHRS, P&A (policy office) is responsible for updating, maintaining and publishing content for this IRM. (
) The HCO, OHRO, HRSS, Work-Life and Leave Sharing Office (program is responsible for the operation and administration of Servicewide work-life wellness programs, including the Lactation Program. (

) The HCO, OHRO, Labor/Employee Relations and Negotiations (LERN) provides guidance and representation to managers in areas such as griev- ances, discipline, adverse and performance cases and contractual obligations with the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU). They assist managers with the complex challenges of balancing employees’ needs for ﬂexibility in their work lives with the IRS’s need to accomplish its mission. (
) The FMSS Division designates a room at locations where there is not a clinic to be used as a lactation room, when requested. Management Review (

) The program office gauges the effectiveness of this program based on feedback from customers and stakeholders and considers any statutory or regulatory changes. During review and publishing, in partnership with HCO, OHRS, P&A, IRM sections are revised, added or deleted based in part on process. (
) Program Reports: The participant spreadsheet is located on the program office Shar
oint site. The purpose of the spreadsheet is for program manager(s) to document employee participants, enrollment dates and with- drawal dates. (
) Program Effectiveness: Program goals are measured through an optional questionnaire that is sent once a participant withdraws from the Lactation Program. (

) Annual Review: An annual review is conducted to determine program effec- tiveness and feasibility. The review requirements are subject to revision as Lactation Program parameters are amended periodically and as the IRS dures are changed. See IRM
, Program Controls below for more information. Controls (

) It is important to continuously assess and evaluate all work-life programs ensure IRS programs deliver the desired effects and outcomes. Assessments of these programs help leadership: a. Understand how often programs are used, b. Track satisfaction rates and

The IRS Human Capital Officer is the executive responsible for this IRM and overall Servicewide policy for work-life and wellness programs.
The FMSS Division designates a room at locations where there is not a health clinic to be used as a lactation room, when requested.
Program Effectiveness: Program goals are measured through an optional exit questionnaire that is sent once a participant withdraws from the Lactation
) The policy office is responsible for reviewing policies to ensure conformance with applicable laws and regulations. (

) The program office is responsible for implementing, monitoring and improving internal controls which are programs and procedures that ensure: a. Program goals are established, and performance is measured to assess efficient and effective objective accomplishment. b. Programs and resources are protected against waste, fraud, abuse, mis- management and misappropriation. c. Program operations are reviewed in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. d. Financial reporting is complete, current and accurate, if required. e. Reliable information is obtained and used in decision making and quality assurance. (

) Annual program review requirements include the program office: a. Ensuring the internal controls are complete, accurate and reviewed at least annually to promote consistent program administration and b. Reviewing the usage of work-life programs to determine which programs are most widely used or least used to adjust program administration ac- cordingly. (
) The following activities ensure program success: a. Conducting annual policy reviews and b. Publishing educational articles and other materials. (

) Alternative lactation room – A temporary lactation room which at a minimum, is a private room shielded from view and free from intrusion from coworkers and the public, is able to lock from the inside and is not a bathroom. It is not required to have a refrigerator. (
) Lactation program participant – An employee who is breastfeeding a child and participating in the Lactation Program. (
) Lactation room – A private room that is shielded from view and free from intrusion from coworkers and the public for an employee to express their breast milk. See IRM
, Designated Lactation Room for more informa- tion. (
) Parental leave – A period of absence from work, granted to an employee before and after the birth of their child. (
) The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions: Acronym Deﬁnition AWS Alternative Work Schedules BU Bargaining Unit CWS Compressed Work Schedules Program

, Enhancing Workplace Flexibilities and Work-Life Programs, at https://chcoc.gov/content/enhancing-workplace- ﬂexibilities-and-work-life-programs . (
) The Employee Assistance Program (EAP) is available to assist employees pregnancy and diet, coping with postpartum depression, returning to work adjusting to parenthood. See IRM
, Employee Assistance & Worklife Referral Program and the IRS Source, at https://irssource.web.irs.gov/Lists/ Worklif
for more information on the EAP. (
) All employees who identify themselves as having a need to express milk are eligible for the Lactation Program, regardless of tenure or part-time, seasonal or full-time work status. (
) Employees have the right to participate in the Lactation Program without fear of retaliation or adverse action. (
) An employee is eligible to participate in the Lactation Program for
months following the birth of their child. However, an employee’s request to continue the Lactation Program longer than
months after the birth of their child should not be unreasonably denied. (

) Employees should enroll in the Lactation Program as soon as practical or to going on parental leave. The earlier the employee identiﬁes themselves, sooner the lactation room identiﬁcation and negotiations may begin, if appli- cable. See the related negotiated MOU, at https://irssource.web.irs.gov/ Linked%
) To participate, employees must: a. Submit an OS Ge

ervices ticket; and select “Request Help>Employee Resources>Work-Life Programs>Health Services>Lactation Program>Lactation Program Enrollment,” b. Call the Employee Resource Center (ERC) (contact information is found on the IRS Source, Lactation Program webpage at https://irssource.web. irs.gov/Lists/Wor
) or c. Request a designee or their manager to submit an OS Ge

) Participants will receive an email upon enrollment (within three workdays) including: a. A link to an electronically-recorded information session, b. The MOU, c. This IRM, d. Guidance on how to request hand sanitizer and disinfecting wipes and Program

ervices ticket; and select “Request Help>Employee Resources>Work-Life Programs>Health Services>Lactation Program>Lactation Program Enrollment,” Call the Employee Resource Center (ERC) (contact information is found on the IRS Source, Lactation Program webpage at https://irssource.web. irs.gov/Lists/Wor
) or Request a designee or their manager to submit an OS Ge

) Employees have the responsibility to make requests for Lactation Program formation, time to review materials, computer access, etc., to their manager. (

) Employees should raise questions or concerns requiring immediate attention their manager for resolution. The manager will make reasonable efforts to address the issues within one workday of notiﬁcation. In the event that a concern is not resolved within one workday or for other concerns, participants should contact the program office by submitting an OS Ge
) To schedule a lactation/conference room(s) for lactation breaks participants can: a. Submit an OS Ge

ervices ticket and select “Request Help>Employee Resources>Work-Life Programs>Health Services>Lactation Program>Lactation Services Needed” or b. Call the ERC (contact information is found on the IRS Source, Lactation Program webpage at https://irssource.web.irs.gov/Lists/ Wor
) Cleanliness must be maintained in the lactation/conference room(s). To request hand sanitizer and disinfecting wipes employees should use their current supply request process. (
) All expressed milk must be stored in closed (and preferably labeled) contain- ers, which must be taken home daily. (
) Participants are responsible for locking the door of the lactation/conference room while expressing milk. See IRM
, Scheduling of the Lactation/Conference Room(s), for more information regarding the lactation/conference room(s). (

) Managers’ responsibilities include: a. Providing employees resources about the Lactation Program, if necessary. b. Providing employees a reasonable amount of time to view all materials provided, consistent with workload and staffing needs. c. Providing employees who do not have access to a computer as part of their job duties access to a computer, if needed. d. Submitting an OS Ge
ervices ticket on the employee’s behalf to help them enroll into the program, if necessary. e. Following appropriate guidelines for obtaining supplies (hand sanitizer and disinfecting wipes). See IRM
). f. Following appropriate guidelines for lactation breaks. See IRM
, Additional Work Schedule Flexibili- ties for Lactation Breaks.

) Participants should raise questions or concerns requiring immediate attention to their manager for resolution. The manager will make reasonable efforts to address the issues within one workday of notiﬁcation. In the event that a concern is not resolved within one workday or for other concerns, participants should contact the program office by submitting an OS Ge
) To withdraw from the Lactation Program, notify the program office by: a. Submitting an OS Ge

ervices ticket and selecting “Request Help>Employee Resources>Work-Life Programs>Health Services>Lactation Program>Withdraw from Program” or b. Calling the ERC (contact information is found on the IRS Source, Lactation Program webpage at https://irssource.web.irs.gov/Lists/ Wor

) Participants may complete an optional exit questionnaire upon withdrawal the Lactation Program. The questionnaire gives participants the opportunity provide feedback, suggestions for improvement and any problems or chal- lenges experienced while participating. a. Participants who do not have access to a computer as part of their job duties will be given access to a computer to complete the online optional exit questionnaire. b. Participants will be given the opportunity to indicate if they would like NTEU to receive a copy of their optional exit questionnaire. If so, there a place for the participant to indicate their applicable chapter number, business unit, city/state and post of duty (POD). c. Upon request, the program office will provide a copy of the completed optional exit questionnaires for program participants to the applicable local NTEU chapter. (

) Participants are provided a reasonable amount of break time to express milk as frequently as needed. The frequency and duration of breaks may vary among participants. The IRS has determined that a Lactation Program partici- pant’s request for a reasonable amount of break time cannot be denied. (

) Normally, a participant will be released at the time they request a break. If staffing and workload requirements prevent management from releasing the participant at the requested time, then management must release the partici- pant at the earliest opportunity after the request is made, normally within one hour of the requested time. (

) If management determines that the request cannot be granted within one hour, management must provide the participant the reason(s) for the denial writing. For BU employees, denials of a requested lactation break are subject

Upon request, the program office will provide a copy of the completed optional exit questionnaires for program participants to the applicable local NTEU chapter.

Participants are provided a reasonable amount of break time to express milk as frequently as needed. The frequency and duration of breaks may vary among participants. The IRS has determined that a Lactation Program partici- pant’s request for a reasonable amount of break time cannot be denied.

If management determines that the request cannot be granted within one hour, management must provide the participant the reason(s) for the denial in writing. For BU employees, denials of a requested lactation break are subject
to the provisions in the negotiated MOU, at http://hco.web.irs.gov/Worklife/PDF/ MOUNursingmother
pdf . Nonbargaining unit (NBU) employees, please refer to IRM

) Management must make reasonable efforts to grant requests from participants (including those who telework), to use annual leave, leave without pay (LWOP), previously earned compensatory time off, previously earned credit hours or to extend a tour of duty (TOD), in accordance with IRM
, Additional Work Schedule Flexibilities for Lactation Breaks, below, to account for lactation breaks taken by participants to express milk. (

) Lactation breaks are not compensated unless the participant is entitled to a compensated break, in which case the participant can use any compensated break to express milk in the designated location. See IRM
, IRS Hours of Duty for more information. For BU employees, breaks are subject to Article
months of the birth of the child, an employee may request to use LWOP, annual leave or if eligible, paid parental leave (PPL) under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) to express milk. (
) For information on annual leave, LWOP, FMLA or PPL, see IRM
, Absence and Leave and the PPL page on the IRS Source at https://irssource. web.irs.gov/Lists/Timekeeping/Dis
. While Lactation gram participants may not use sick leave for lactation breaks, information on sick leave for the birth and care of a child may also be found in IRM
, Absence and Leave. BU employees should see Articles
) Management may approve requests for changes to Alternative Work Schedules (AWS) for participants who need time off to express milk during normal working hours. (

) Participation in the Lactation Program should not affect a participant’s eligibility to remain on their current AWS, whether it is a Flexible Work Schedule (FWS) or a Compressed Work Schedule (CWS) and/or their ability to earn or use credit hours or compensatory time off. (

) Participants on an FWS (Flexitour with Credit Hours, Maxiﬂex or Gliding) can accommodate lactation breaks by requesting to: a. Use previously earned credit hours, b. Use previously earned compensatory time off (earned in accordance applicable premium pay law, regulation and policy) or c. Earn credit hours before or after their TOD for lactation breaks taken another workday. Note: Participants must ﬁrst earn credit hours before they can use them. Therefore, a participant can only use previously earned credit hours for their breaks taken on another workday. For example, a participant on an FWS (with a one-hour accumulated credit
Note: Participants must ﬁrst earn credit hours before they can use them. Therefore, a participant can only use previously earned credit hours for their breaks taken on another workday.

For example, a participant on an FWS (with a one-hour accumulated credit hour balance) who works a TOD of 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., with a one-hour unpaid lunch or meal period, can request two 30 minute credit hour periods during the day to express milk. At the end of their TOD, the participant could, with
prior managerial approval, earn one credit hour from
p.m. This would give the participant a one-hour accumulated credit hour balance when they begin their next workday. (
) Lactation program participants on a CWS (

) are not eligible to earn or use credit hours. However, participants on a CWS, may use previously earned compensatory time off (earned in accordance with applicable premium pay law, regulation and policy) for lactation breaks. (

) With prior managerial approval, a participant may request a one-hour unpaid lunch or meal period. The one-hour unpaid lunch or meal period may be used for the participant’s lunch or meal period and/or unpaid lactation breaks. The unpaid lactation breaks do not have to be taken at a speciﬁc time during the TOD, even though they are considered part of the participant’s daily lunch or meal period. The timeframe may be split up into one
-minute unpaid lunch or meal period and one
-minute unpaid lunch or meal period and two

-minute unpaid lactation breaks to accommo- date for the lactation time taken throughout the employee’s TOD. An unpaid lunch or meal period or the additional unpaid breaks comprised of the lunch meal period, may not be combined with a paid break. For BU employees, denials of a requested lactation break are subject to the provisions in the ne- gotiated MOU, at https://irssource.web.irs.gov/ Linked%
OU.pdf . NBU employees please refer to IRM

, Agency Grievance System - Agency Grievance. Note: In no case will an extension for this purpose result in increased costs to the IRS (for example, premium pay or additional night pay differential). (
) For more information on breaks, AWS or credit hours, see IRM
, IRS Hours of Duty. For information on premium pay and compensatory time off see IRM
and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Compensatory Time Off for Travel. BU employees should see Articles

) The program office will contact the FMSS Division to designate a lactation room in an existing IRS-controlled space as needed in each POD when the ﬁrst employee in that POD identiﬁes themselves and becomes a participant in the Lactation Program. Note: New or newly remodeled IRS PODs may contain a room permanently desig- nated as a lactation room within their ﬂoor plan. (

) The designated lactation room will be a private space shielded from view and free from intrusion from employees and the public. The lactation room will be: a. A designated room within the POD or b. Within the POD’s health clinic. (

) The designated lactation room will be cleaned regularly with the same level of service as other office rooms receive and be equipped with at least the following IRS provided equipment: a. A table, b. A comfortable chair, c. One small refrigerator,
prior managerial approval, earn one credit hour from 5 p.m. to 6 p.m. This would give the participant a one-hour accumulated credit hour balance when they begin their next workday.
would give the participant a one-hour accumulated credit hour balance when they begin their next workday. (
) Lactation program participants on a CWS (

The one-hour unpaid lunch or meal period may be used for the participant’s lunch or meal period and/or unpaid lactation breaks. The unpaid lactation breaks do not have to be taken at a speciﬁc time during the TOD, even though they are considered part of the participant’s daily lunch or meal period. ) The program office will contact the FMSS Division to designate a lactation room in an existing IRS-controlled space as needed in each POD when the ﬁrst employee in that POD identiﬁes themselves and becomes a participant in
Note: New or newly remodeled IRS PODs may contain a room permanently desig- nated as a lactation room within their ﬂoor plan.

) The designated lactation room will be a private space shielded from view and free from intrusion from employees and the public. The lactation room will be: a. A designated room within the POD or b. Within the POD’s health clinic. (
) The designated lactation room will be cleaned regularly with the same level of service as other office rooms receive and be equipped with at least the following IRS provided equipment: a. A table,
(2) The designated lactation room will be a private space shielded from view and free from intrusion from employees and the public. The lactation room will be:
d. One trash can and e. An electrical outlet. Note: For any equipment concerns, submit an OS Ge
ervices ticket and select “Request Help>Employee Resources>Work-Life Programs>Health Services>Lactation Program>Lactation Services Needed.” (
) The designated lactation room will not be a bathroom. (
) The designated lactation room will be able to lock from the inside. (

) In each POD with a health clinic, the designated lactation room will be located inside the health clinic. In the event that a participant or NTEU raises a concern that the health clinic room does not contain the required equipment, inconsistent with this IRM or is inappropriate for use by Lactation Program ticipants, the participant or NTEU should submit an OS Ge

ervices ticket indicating the issue as a health and safety concern. While the program office investigates the concern, it will designate an alternative location for Lactation Program participants to use. (
) The lactation room may be used as a conference room when not being used by a participant. (

) Should the number of Lactation Program participants in a POD rise to a level at which another room is needed to accommodate multiple Lactation Program participants, the program office will contact the FMSS Division to designate additional lactation room, which complies with this policy and the negotiated MOU, for the time necessary. (

) In the event there are no Lactation Program participants identiﬁed at a POD, the room will return to its original use. As soon as a new participant in that POD has identiﬁed themselves; then, the room is designated as a lactation room again. (

) Participants must follow the scheduling procedures for their POD or health clinic when possible. Lactation program participants will be given priority to reserve the designated lactation room. This priority means the Lactation Program participants can and should schedule their breaks in advance so another IRS employee, including another Lactation Program participant, change, modify or cancel a participant’s previously scheduled lactation room reservation. Priority does not mean that a Lactation Program participant can turn away another participant who properly scheduled time to use the lactation room if they change their regularly scheduled break time. Note: In small PODs where there is one conference room, there may be rare cir- cumstances in which IRS employees may need the conference room for meeting on short notice. In such situations, the program office will provide the participant an alternative lactation room. (

Note: In small PODs where there is one conference room, there may be rare cir- cumstances in which IRS employees may need the conference room for a meeting on short notice. In such situations, the program office will provide the participant an alternative lactation room. (

) A participant may request a change in their regularly scheduled breaks. If the designated conference/lactation room is unavailable, the program office will make reasonable efforts to ﬁnd an alternative lactation room. (
) If there are multiple Lactation Program participants in the same POD, they will be able to schedule use of the lactation room on a ﬁrst come, ﬁrst serve basis.

) Each Lactation Program participant will be given a welcome package, which provides participants with the basic rules to follow for using a designated lactation room, including the priority scheduling for Lactation Program partici- pants. ) When a designated lactation room uses a digital scheduling program, it will be used for scheduling. When the lactation room is within the health clinic, partici- pants will schedule time in the lactation room with the health clinic nurse. Program

When a designated lactation room uses a digital scheduling program, it will be used for scheduling. When the lactation room is within the health clinic, partici- pants will schedule time in the lactation room with the health clinic nurse.
